review.title: Learning Light Transport the Reinforced Way
review.abstract: We show that the equations of reinforcement learning and light transport simulation are related integral equations. Based on this correspondence, a scheme to learn importance while sampling path space is derived. The new approach is demonstrated in a consistent light transport simulation algorithm that uses reinforcement learning to progressively learn where light comes from. As using this information for importance sampling includes information about visibility, too, the number of light transport paths with non-zero contribution is dramatically increased, resulting in much less noisy images within a fixed time budget.

sections.text: An application of light transport simulation is a simple and efficient online method that can significantly reduce the number of light transport routes. [1] One application of light transport simulation is the computational synthesis of images that cannot be distinguished from real photos. [2] In such simulation algorithms, light transport is modelled by a Fredholm integral equation that allows an integral equation of light sources and camera sensors. [3] The estimators are an average of sampled light transport paths linking light sources and camera types. Compared to reality, where photons and their trajectories are abundant, a computer can only consider a tiny fraction of the path space, which is one of the dominant reasons for noisy images. sections.heading: 3.3 Environment Lighting
sections.text: The representation of sun and sky is usually done by distributing samples proportional to the brightness of pixels in the ambient texture. Further samples should land in brighter regions, which is achieved by constructing and scanning a cumulative distribution function, e.g. using the alias method [30]. In addition, the sun can be separated from the sky and simulated separately. The efficiency of such scanning strongly depends on occlusion, i.e. on which part of the environment can be seen from the shaded point (see Fig. 1). Similar to Fig. 3.1 and to take into account the actual contribution including occlusion, an action space is defined by dividing the ambient map into tiles and learning the meaning per tile. Fig. 5 shows the improvement for an example scenario.

sections.heading: 4 Temporal Difference Learning and Next Event Estimation
sections.text: In addition to the known shortcomings of (bidirectional) path tracking [15, Sec.2.4 Problem of insufficient techniques], efficiency may be limited by the approximate quality of Q: The smaller the light sources, for example, the finer the resolution of Q required to reliably conduct rays to hit a light source. At this point, the next event estimation may be helpful. Already in [33], the contribution of light sources has been "learned": A probability per light source is stored by the number of successful shadow rays divided by the total number of shadow rays. This idea was subsequently refined [14, 32, 2, 31]. To enhance learning, the state space can be selected as a regular grid above the scene, in which in each grid cell c for each light source l a value Vc, l is stored, divided by the total number of volcanic rays. sections.heading: 4.1 Learning Virtual Point Light Sources
sections.text: The vertices generated by tracking photon trajectories (see paragraph 3.4) can be viewed as a photon map [9] and used in the same way. In addition, they can be used as a series of virtual point light sources, for example for the Instant Radiosity [11] algorithm. Continuous updating and learning of the W [25] measurement contribution function across frames and using the same seed for the pseudo or quasi-random sequences allow the generation of virtual point light sources that have a certain coherence over time, which reduces temporal artifacts when displaying animations with global illumination.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We introduced a new algorithm to increase the efficiency of path tracking by approaching the importance of amplification learning during image synthesis. By identifying Q-learning and light transport, heuristics have been replaced by physically based functions, and the only parameters the user can control are the learning rate and discretization of Q.The combination of amplification learning and deep neural networks [19, 7, 17, 18] is an obvious path for future research: radiation in hemispheres has already been successfully researched [22] and the interesting question is how well Q can be represented by neural networks.
